title: 106_hr5272
content: On March 16, 1999, the House of Representatives adopted House Concurrent Resolution 24, stating that any attempt to establish Palestinian statehood outside the negotiating process will face strong congressional opposition. On July 25, 2000, Palestinian Chairman Arafat and Israeli Prime Minister Barak agreed to avoid unilateral actions that could impact negotiations. The United States opposes the unilateral declaration of a Palestinian state and will not recognize it diplomatically. Other countries and international organizations are encouraged to do the same. Measures will be taken if a Palestinian state is unilaterally declared. Measures will be applied if a Palestinian state is unilaterally declared, including downgrading the status of the Palestinian office in the United States as per the Foreign Relations Authorization Act. The Foreign Relations Authorization Act, despite any waivers or suspensions, includes the Palestinian Authority and any unilaterally declared Palestinian state under the term "Palestine Liberation Organization." This does not prevent the establishment of a Palestinian information office in the United States. The Foreign Relations Authorization Act prohibits United States assistance to a unilaterally declared Palestinian state, the Palestinian Authority, or any related entity. Assistance (except humanitarian aid) is also prohibited to programs in the West Bank and Gaza. The President is authorized to withhold up to 10 percent of the United States contributions to international organizations that recognize a unilaterally declared Palestinian state. This includes reducing voluntary contributions by up to 10 percent below the previous fiscal year's level. The Secretary of the Treasury will oppose international financial institutions recognizing a unilaterally declared Palestinian state and providing any financial assistance to it. No funds can be used to extend US recognition to a unilaterally declared Palestinian state, including salaries for diplomatic personnel or costs for establishing diplomatic facilities. This assistance includes peacekeeping operations, assistance under the Arms Export Control Act, and assistance under the Export-Import Bank Act of 1945, but does not include counter-terrorism assistance. The House of Representatives passed H.R. 5272 on September 27, 2000, providing for a U.S. response to a unilateral declaration of a Palestinian state. The bill was read for the first time on September 28, 2000.
